dict.string: Prevent user from running Settings Manager on its own

Please use the Settings Manager by launching the main macro, then pressing Control while the delay box is onscreen.
If the Settings Manager is run directly, key variables aren't set, and it won't work properly.
The Settings Manager is not a standalone macro

__ Press Escape to cancel backup backup__ Exit Settings Manager and run back up __1️⃣ BACKUPS ━━━━━━ buname__ Change folder name buloc__ Change location (and move existing) buqty__ How many to keep links__ Use of hard links delay__ Change delay before start __2️⃣ INTERFACE ━━━━━━ dialog__ Manage onscreen information timer__ Control how the task timer operates timing__ Show or hide timing info in report labels__ Enable or disable Finder labels
Offer the option to reset invisible and duplicate warnings, if disabled
__3️⃣ OPERATION ━━━━━━ warn__ Reset the duplicates/invisibles warnings
If export is in manual mode, offter chance to try automatic again
Present the Settings Manager options list
Split the backup path for future use
Present renaming dialog until properly completed or canceled

Note: The only safety checks provided for the new name are that it cannot begin with a period, nor contain a colon. Please use macOS-safe naming!
The current name is: %Variable%local_BUfolder%
Please enter the new name for your backup folder
Your backup folder has been renamed...

When the standard file browsing dialog appears, please select the folder that will hold %Variable%local_BUfolder%.
After selecting the new folder, you will be asked if you'd like to move your existing backups to the new location or not. If you choose not to move them, the next backup will be your first backup, and analysis will begin again with the next backup.
Current location: %Variable%rg_MBU_BackupLoc%
*** DO NOT USE A NETWORKED OR CLOUD DRIVE! *** I have not tested the macro with such a setup, and I have no idea what may happen.
Choose the folder where %Variable%local_BUfolder% will reside…
Choose the folder that will store %Variable%local_BUfolder%
Set temp var with location of old backup
Set global variable to the new backup folder location
Create the folder to hold the backups
And the folder for the database

All future backups will be placed here: %Variable%rg_MBU_BackupLoc%
Would you like to move your existing backups to this new location?
NOTE: It is *highly* recommended you have a backup of your backups before doing this, just in case something goes awry.
The backup folder has been changed…
Handle moving files across, if user requested that
Create the new alias via AppleScript

set apscDone1 to false set loopCount1 to 0 repeat until apscDone1 is true or loopCount1 is 15 try --if application "Keyboard Maestro Engine" is not running then tell application "Keyboard Maestro Engine" to launch try set kmInst to system attribute "KMINSTANCE" tell application "Keyboard Maestro Engine" set theLocation to getvariable "rg_MBU_BackupLoc" set theFolderToAlias to getvariable "instance_NewestFolderName" instance kmInst end tell set myPath to theLocation & "/" & theFolderToAlias tell application "Finder" make new alias at POSIX file theLocation to POSIX file myPath set name of result to "__latest" end tell end try set apscDone1 to true on error set apscDone1 to false set loopCount1 to loopCount1 + 1 end try end repeat

dict.string:
The copy failed to verify. Please remove the files in the new backup location and try again. If this continues to fail, please get in touch with me on the Keyboard Maestro forums for assistance.
The macro will now exit.

dict.string:
The verification test passed; your copied backups are identical to the originals. Would you like the macro to delete the originals, or would you rather do that yourself?
If you choose to do it yourself, you'll be returned to the settings manager; if you choose to delete the originals, you'll see a message when that's done and then you'll return to the settings manager.
Yes => Delete the originals No => Keep the originals
You did have a backup of your backups, right??
Set text based on current limit

You have a current cap of %Variable%instance_BackupQty% backups. Enter a new limit, or enter any negative number to not have a cap.
If you enter a cap that is lower than the number of backups you currently have, extra backups will be removed when the next backup runs.
You currently do not have a limit on the number of backups. If you'd like to set a limit, enter a positive number, at least two or higher.
Handle the input, trapping for bad data
Set a new limit on the number of backups to keep
You must have at least two backups
SQL: Update settings database with new value
Display one of two notifications depending on setting chosen
You set a negative backup limit, which means there is no limit—the macro will never remove any backup files.
Your new limit is %Variable%instance_BackupQty%. Backups over the limit will be removed on next backup.
Create two different sets of text based on current setting

Your backups were not created using hard links—every file is on the drive multiple times, requiring much more drive space. Click Enable Hard Links to use them starting with the next backup (existing backups are not changed).
You'll save a lot of space going forward, though maintaining the hard links when you copy your backups to another drive is trickier. (You have to use rsync in Terminal; see the Read Me First! macro for more on that.)
Click Cancel to continue making full copy backups.
SQL: Update settings database with new value

Your backups were created using space-saving hard links. Click Disable Hard Links to *not* use hard links on future backups (no existing backups will be modified.)
This will require much more drive space, but the resulting backups are more easily copied between machines without worrying about breaking hard links.
Click Cancel to leave hard links enabled.
SQL: Update settings database with new value
Delay: Set length of delay before backup starts

When launched, MacroBackerUpper pauses three seconds, which gives you time to enter the Settings Manager (and/or cancel the backup). You can change this delay to any number you like, as long as it's at least one (integers only, please).
Current setting: %Variable%instance_TimerDelay% seconds.
Pause for how long before beginning backup?
SQL: Update settings database with new value
Progress list and summary dialog: When to show or hide
Always Only if macro manually triggered Never
Remove the current setting from the list

During a backup, a task list shows the macro's progress, followed by a backup summary dialog when done. You can opt to have these two things always displayed (the default), only have them displayed when you trigger the macro manually, or to never see them.
Current setting: %Variable%instance_ShowDialog%
Pick one of the other two choices if you'd like to change it.
When to see onscreen progress and summary data?
SQL: Update settings database with new value
Translate instance var to dialog language
Remove the current setting from the list

MacroBackerUpper tracks time taken during each part of the backup. You can choose how much of this data you'd like to see:
• Notification: You'll see one notification at the end (default). • Window: As above, but in a window, not a notification. • Silence: There is no end-of-run notification of any sort. • All: Every task creates a notification—not recommended!
Current setting: %Variable%local_CurrentTimerOption%
How much timing data would you like to see?
Translate answer into the timer's language
SQL: Update settings database with new value
The new setting is: %Variable%localTimerType__Choose an option%
Currently, the saved report includes detailed timing on every task in the backup. Click Disable Timing to remove this, or Cancel to keep the timing data on the report.
Show detailed timing data in report?
Currently, the saved report does not include any detailed timing information. Click Enable Timing to add it to the next backup run's saved report, or click Cancel to leave things as they are.
Show detailed timing data in report?
SQL: Update settings database with new value

Currently, Finder labels are enabled, so new macro groups are labeled in green, modified in yellow, etc. Click Disable Labels to turn Finder labels off for future backups, or click Cancel to leave them enabled.
Use Finder labels to distinguish changes?

Currently, Finder labels are disabled. If enabled, then new macro groups are labeled in green, modified in yellow, etc. Click Enable Labels to turn Finder labels on for future backups, or click Cancel to leave them disabled.
Use Finder labels to distinguish changes?
SQL: Update settings database with new value
Update the settings in the database
UPDATE s_MacroBackerUpper SET Warn_Dupes = 'Yes'; UPDATE s_MacroBackerUpper SET Warn_Invisibles = 'Yes'
SQL: Update settings database with new values
You will receive a warning if any such macros/groups are found on the next backup run.
